title: masterchef its all cooking with wokes not woks
story: The cook was Dominic ­Little-wood, the venue Battersea’s Cinnamon Kitchen, which suddenly began filling with an acrid stench and a cloud of battery acid after he accidentally baked an egg-timer instead of a naan bread.Diners coughed, waiters bolted for the front door and Sam Quek shouted: “What time is it, Dom ”But before anyone could answer or staff were hospitalised, the fire was out and the fun was over for another  years.This is, after all, Celebrity MasterChef, a relentless, formula-driven monster of a show where spontaneity is rarely on the menu.What you’ve got instead are two adequate hosts, John Torode and Gregg Wallace, organising endless rounds of cooking that lead nowhere except more rounds of cooking.Until eventually, several months down the line, someone is declared the winner and then turns up on the next series judging the food and generally acting like they’re Gordon Ramsay.Normally, though, you’ll know exactly who that’s going to be, weeks in advance, as the booking process is as regimented as everything  on this BBC show and designed to fulfil quotas as much it is to entertain.Every week there are five contestants and one must be a clumsy, have-a-go bloke, in the Dom mould, who’d clearly be far more at home shting pianos in a PG Tips advert than cooking.Form also dictates there’s a tiresomely “competitive” sports-person, like Sam Quek , a completely anonymous box-ticker, who turns out to be Karen Gibson, the choir-conductor at Meghan and Harry’s wedding, and Quadrophenia star Phil Daniels fulfilling the role of “the one you actually recognise and like”.The sucker-punch, however, is “the one you neither recognise nor like”, who ­generally comes from the attention- seeking end of the reality market.In this instance it’s someone called Baga Chipz, who caused a ripple or two on Ru Paul’s Drag Race, last year and now clearly thinks: “I’m the new Dame Edna.”There are worrying signs some people at the BBC may agree as well, because Baga was treated with a certain reverence by John and Gregg and referred to by the pronouns “she” and “her” despite the fact that underneath all that make-up there isa bloke called Leo Loren.Underneath all that make-up, it ­transpires, there’s also a signicant ego as viewers discovered when Baga Cement left the show, at a canter, declaring: “I can bring the comedy gold and telly, but I can’t cook.”Dom was next off and I was almost sad to see him go as, quite apart from melting an egg-timer, he’d produced one of my favourite ever MasterChef dishes — chicken stir fry in a ­hollowed-out pineapple.You wouldn’t want to tread in it, let alone eat it, obviously, but the show needs these distractions.Without them, Celebrity MasterChef tells you only two things: Where the celebs are at and where the BBC’s head is at.Where it should be at, of course, is dreaming up bold and imaginative new formats to see us through this dficult time.What it’s actually doing at the moment, though, is dreaming up bold and imaginative new ways to tick boxes.Starting tomorrow, when Celebrity ­MasterChef welcomes its first blind ­contestant, Amar Lat.“What time is it, Dom ”Bloody Chico time, probably. MORE than a week on from ITV’s Bullseye revival, with Alan Carr, I’m still brooding over this Epic Gameshow debacle.Obvious parts of the problem were the scheduling and the format tweaks, which introduced lelines, golden darts and spinning boards as well as a whole level of irony.It wasn’t until I spent a few days watching some glorious Challenge TV repeats of the original, though, that I twigged the over-riding issue was the personnel – particularly the s audience, who were always immaculate, and the contestants, who belonged to another world, where people had proper jobsand appearing on TV was a luxury not a birthright.On Alan Carr’s version, by contrast, they were the usual over-sharing, part-building show-offs we’ve come to expect from gameshows.On the  series, however, they seem almost unnaturally shy and have definitely arrived at the studio to win a car and some money rather than share details of their private or professional lives.It could be, of course, that they’re slightly in awe of Jim Bowen.Neither before nor since has there ever been anyone quite like the original host, who is both deliberately and accidentally hilarious.A man visibly surprised when one of the female contestants hits the right target and utterly thunderstruck when another responds correctly to the question: “Can you name the banned South African political party Oliver Tambo is a member of ”“The African National Congress.” “WOW! You are a clever girl, Sue.”It’s a little bit patronising, admittedly and he’d be hauled through every kangaroo court in the country for saying that out loud now.But I’ll take Jim’s innocent version of television before I take ’s joyless, humourless woke wasteland all day long, thanks very much. It’s a happier place.INCIDENTALLY, Loose Women, Janet Street- Porter: “If I was an animal I’d be a terrapin.”What’s technically known as horse-s***.MEANWHILE, on episode three of Celebrity Snoop Dogs, a pug called Colin is snfing around a weight-training room as Channel ’s Kevin McCloud builds to the big reveal.“More eye-catching, though, is that plaque behind the microphone. Could it belong to ­someone who’s good at making people laugh “It’s Russell Kane!” No, it couldn’t.HOW television works .Someone a BBC continuity announcer described as “the wonderful Maxine Peake” starred in last week’s Talking Heads, a fortnight after sharing an anti-Semitic conspiracy theory about George Floyd’s death, with The Independent.Miriam Margolyes s to the Beeb shortly, with her Almost Australian travelogue, despite telling Channel ’s Last Leg she wanted the Prime Minister to die of coronavirus.But actor Laurence Fox is unemployable and considered a public pariah, by the industry, because he told Question Time that Britain was “the most tolerant, lovely country in Europe”.One rule for one, quite another for Corbynistas.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Asteroid  Audrey is named after which actress ”Marina: “Kim Basinger.”Tenable, Warwick Davis: “Name the ten largest countries in South America.” Devon: “Hungary.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “In  -year-old Judit Polgar became the youngest ­international grandmaster of which board game ”Helena: “Monopoly.”Ben Shephard: “Mayo is the Spanish word for which month of the year ”Rick: “March.”GOOD Morning Britain, Monday, Piers: “What about this  At my local Italian ­restaurant, on Saturday, after all this showing-each- other-more-kindness talk, there were  no-shows.”Then Piers turned up. Problem solved. So what about it HAVING failed to conquer Hollywood or overthrow international capitalism Russell Brand took on a slightly more manageable project, last week.A cameo in Neighbours where he literally bumped into Toadie, eating a muffin, at the Harold Bishop cafe.“You’re Russell Brand! What are you doing here in Erinsborough ”“Well, you know,” said Brand, “Get Him To The Greek, The Trews, socialism, Ed Miliband. It all went horribly wrong.“So it was either this or a Postcode Lottery advert, with Jeff Brazier.”Actually, he said no such thing.He made a funny, self-mocking speech about the irony of mobile phones being “emblems of interconnectivity, yet we’re more atomised, adrt and lost than ever before”, then went to order a coffee.And I’ve got no hesitation in saying, I think it’s his finest ever work.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fast fashion firms smarten act end modern slavery
story: This apparent modern slavery has no place in fashion. It has no place anywhere. It is often a breach of human rights. It is often illegal.So it is understandable that many of us are questioning why this is happening – and, by extension, what our role is in this.Has our desire for cheap and cheerful fashion created this sickening practice  Are we somehow to blame for insisting we will only pay as little as possible for everything Should we — as some smarmy “influencers” suggest — be boycotting anyone who sells cheap clothes The simple answer is: NoOf course, in an ideal world, we’d all be buying top quality, ethically sourced garments that last a letime.But that’s just not going to happen. Most people just can’t afford to. And we like to keep up with trends while at the same time paying the bills. There is nothing wrong with that.Our love of fashion keeps the economy going.Fashion is the UK’s largest creative industry. It provides jobs for almost as many people as the financial sector and is one of the most female-dominated industries in the world.Around , people work in the UK fashion industry and approximately  per cent of garment workers are women.Livelihoods are at stakewe decide to boycott fashion brands because of their bad practices.The answer is for fast fashion firms like Boohoo and Quiz to do the work and get their houses in order. This is on them.And big firms like Boohoo — a business worth £.billion — are not without means. They have the resources to make changes.They need to perform due diligence on who is making their clothes — they must forensically examine the whole supply chain, from contractors to sub-contractors and anyone  who has a hand in how this stuff comes to market.Decent wages must be the norm. They must be transparent and tell us, the consumer, what they know.This is not rocket science. It is already happening.The Fashion Transparency Index  ranks  of the biggest global fashion brands according to how much information they provide about their suppliers, supply chain policies and practices and social and environmental impact.Retailers are scored on their transparency across five key areas: Policy and commitments, governance, traceability, supplier assessment and remediation and spotlight issues.HM, one of the largest fashion retailers in the world, is currently top of The Fashion Transparency Index.Stung by allegations that its clothes had been made by child labour in Myanmar — with some paid as little as p an hour — it last year built a new tracking system so consumers can find out where each garment is made.Marks  Spencer also scored highly. It introduced an ethical trading programme including audits of its supply chain in the Nineties.Eleven more brands in the Fashion Index revealed details of their processing facilities — where finishing, dyeing and laundering take place — in  compared to .And ten brands disclosed their raw material suppliers in , compared with just one in .Of course this isn’t just a fast fashion problem. It is industry-wide.What customers need from all brands is transparency, as this leads to accountability and ultimately change.Soyou do want to spend your hard-earned cash on fast fashion, only shop at places where you know they are doing their bit to ensure things are more ethically sourced.AS much as I love new clothes, fast fashion has had its day.Two brands have recently been at the centre of allegations that garments are being made or packed in dire working conditions in Leicester.Boohoo has paid a heavy price for these claims, with more than a billion pounds wiped off the value of its shares.Today, it suffered another big fall after a leading investor sold out on ethical grounds.And rival Quiz was sucked into the growing storm. It has suspended a supplier after claims that a factory in Leicester offered a worker just £ an hour to make its clothes.Quiz admitted that the situation, which it is investigating, is “unacceptable”.As online retailers specialising in casualwear, these companies were riding high after lockdown boosted sales. Following these allegations, the tide is turning against them.It comes after lockdown prompted many of us to reassess our lives, with the desire to be greener high on the agenda.A recent survey showed that more women were willing to make do and mend. That can’t be a bad thing.A common reason that clothes are sent to landfill is a missing button, which is simply appalling.Before buying a new dress or jacket, I now ask myself, ‘Am I going to wear this item for years ’Fashion is a global industry worth more than £trillion a year. It will clean itself up where necessary and adapt.Boohoo and Quiz have been swt to terminate relationships with rogue suppliers. Elsewhere, there is much talk of “respons-ible” and “sustainable” fashion.Don’t be surprisedthe fast fashion pack gives itself a long overdue makeover. Hopefully it will be more than the latest fad.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nicola sturgeon snp pandemic independence agenda
story: NICOLA Sturgeon and the SNP are using a global health pandemic to cynically pursue the independence agenda – and the BBC is helping them to do it.The scheming First Minister’s egregious threat to impose a border between Scotland and England is as isive as it is illegal.How can the mainstream media be giving her a free pass on such an outrageous Trump-like threat Make no mistake that this is the SNP suggesting the imposition of some sort of border that doesn’t exist by stealth between the countries of the UK under the cloak of a public health emergency.As Andrew Bowie – the Scottish vice chairman of the Tory party – told my talkRADIO show yesterday such a move would put thousands of Scottish jobs in the hospitality and tourism industry who rely on visits from England in jeopardy.But luckily he said the UK Government will not “stand by and let that happen”.Sturgeon’s dangerous position adds to her constant undermining of the UK government, which sees the SNP loudly criticise any new moves introduced by Westminster only to follow suit a fortnight later.Unsurprisingly, the BBC is buying into the SNP’s narrative hook, line and sinker.Scottish Editor Sarah Smith used the flagship UK pm news bulletin last night to broadcast a feature that was nothing short of a Sturgeon puff piece, lacking in any balance or criticism of her appalling early response to this pandemic.There was no mention of the anaemic Scottish testing regime, the cover up of an early outbreak or the devastating care home death toll.Instead, the Beeb decided to present as fact the idea that Scottish independence is an almost inevitable response to this health crisis.Hardly. Scotland’s government has had to be propped up every step of the way by Westminster.Sturgeon is a good TV performer, I’ll give her that.She’s adored by the international media in the same way New Zealand’s Jacinda Ardern is. But the facts on the ground do not match the rhetoric.Anda right-wing politician was suggesting the introduction of a border blocking free movement by citizens of the UK we would never hear the end of it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: banning huawei from uks 5g network is a good day for britain and a great day for freedom
story: People must be under no illusion: Huawei is to all intents and purposes a Chinese state company.Nothing that the company does can go against the Chinese Communist Partythat rules that state.And given this fact, it was not just wrong but reckless of the UK to even think of having the company involved in the creation of our sensitive networks.Now we will inevitably pay more for G as costs rise by £billion — and we will have to wait a further two to three years for it to be rolled out. Of course, whatever the cost becomes, it is less than the cost of the threat to our national security and is a price we must pay. We were warned repeatedly by all of our allies about involving Huawei in our communications network.In recent years, I have heard first-hand from each of our intelligence-sharing partners in the so-called “Five Eyes” network . All of these countries, our closest allies, have been deeply worried by Britain’s decision. All have warned that this country — and our relationships with our allies — would be compromisedwe allowed Huawei such access. We would have been vulnerable, they warned.Bizarrely, Theresa May ignored this advice, then Boris Johnson’s government originally went further down this terrible road.This, despite the fact that other companies — including US firms — could have provided just the same technology, without the same security risks.And, key sources tell me, all for the same price. Still the Government snubbed our allies, alarmed our friends, and stuck to their decision.Privately it was briefed out that our own security services were confident of their ability to get backdoor access to see what Huawei would be doing and to control any covert activity. But all of this seemed a ridiculously high-risk venture. And for what exactly  Fortunately, that bizarre decision got reversed yesterday.Several factors have contributed to it. The first is an obvious change in relations towards China that is going on around the world. Covid- has played a part. China — unwittingly or carelessly — gave the world a virus which has all but halted our economies.The CCP’s lies and cover-ups during this devastating period have meant that all of us have been confined to our houses for months — and not just those who have contracted the coronavirus that came from Wuhan.In the months and years ahead, all of us will be poorer because of the CCP’s lies. The state has disappeared its own scientists. It allowed travel even after it knew what it was dealing with. It lied about the nature of the virus.And other members of the Five Eyes network have suggested that the evidence points clearly to the virus having been created in a Chinese laboratory.President Trump and his Secretary of State, Mike Pompeo, have rightly made an issue of this. Both have been warning for years about the instability of China as a partner. As recent events in Hong Kong should remind us, China is a one-party, totalitarian state. It rules by dictatorship and terror. Of course, it is also highly technologically skilled and financially ever more dominant.The CCP seeks to make China the world’s leading power. Washington is — rightly — determined to stop that. And this country —we value freedom and the rule of law, as we always have — should seek to stop that too.This means, among much , denying China and Chinese state companies from extending their grip in countries like ours.For years, Chinese companies have stolen information, ripped off s, and otherwise acted completely unlawfully. They have engaged in espionage and information theft on an industrial scale.Some people might look at yesterday’s decision and think it a small, technical matter. It isn’t.Not only is it a decision with far-reaching consequences for this country’s security. It is also a signal of which side this country will be on in one of the most important tussles of our day.Everywhere China seeks to extend its power is an area where freedom recedes.Yesterday was a bad day for Huawei, a good day for Britain and a great day for freedom.Q: WHAT is the new ruling on Huawei A: From the end of this year, telecoms firms will not be able to buy any new Huawei hardware, such as antennas, to put into their G networks. By the end of , all Huawei equipment must be stripped out of the UK’s G networks.Q: Why is G important A: It will be ten times faster than G and allow more complicated technology, such as driverless cars, to operate.Q: What is Huawei currently used for A: The firm is the leading provider of technology needed to operate wireless networks that provide the G signal on our mobile phones. They were going to be used for “non-core” equipment in the G network. Instead European firms Nokia or Erion are likely to provide the hardware.Q: Can I still use my Huawei mobile phone A: Yes. There is no plan to ban its handsets.Q: Will the ban affect my phone signal A: Some telecom firms have warned that stripping out all Huawei hardware too quickly could result in a temporary loss of signal in some places, but other experts say this concern has been exaggerated.Q: Does this affect full fibre broadband connections A: Not at the moment. The Government’s security advisers have only recommended “transitioning away” from Huawei when it comes to fibre networks.Q: Will I have to replace a Huawei router in my home A: The router is not part of the G infrastructure and won’t be affected.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wear a mask to the shops its not a big deal
story: The moaning over their compulsory use in shops from next Friday is ridiculous.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSome pretend it is a grotesque assault on our civil liberties — a “monstrous imposition”, one daft Tory backbencher called it. It really isn’t. Nor will refusing to wear one make someone a hero. If their reluctance is just vanity or embarrassment, they should get over themselves. A mask’s main purpose is to protect ­others. That’s reason enough.That’s not to say we don’t have a few doubts. Health Secretary Matt Hancock says masks “give people more confidence to shop safely”. Well, perhaps. But one new survey indicates that half of families will be scared away from shopsthe Government really considers them that dangerous.We only hope they are vastly outnumbered by those who DO feel safer — or the new edict will strangle our feeble­-looking recovery instead of boosting it.Plus, we have to ask: when will the new rules end  Is there a plan The Government was farcically late imposing them. The Sun backed masks when there were , new UK Covid cases a day. It’s now a tenth of that and the risk of catching it very, very small. How low must daily infections be before we ditch masks . . .     Zero On balance, we still believe their routine use, along with social distancing and hand washing, are our three best forms of self-defence. For now.But normality mustrapidly or our economic prospects are unthinkably grim.  THOSE dire prospects are starkly exposed in the latest woeful economic data.It should be no surprise that growth saw only a slight uptick in May. Shops and pubs still weren’t open. Even so, a . per cent rise barely registers against the . per cent fall in March and April.There’s even worse news on jobs: unemployment is forecast to triple by Christmas, while our deficit hits a mind-boggling £billion for the year.We celebrated when Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane said a swt V-shaped recovery was under way.We now wonder what he’s been smoking.FOR a decade Britain cosied up to a ­Chinese regime which has increasingly revealed itself to be malign.The belated Huawei U-turn must be just a first step in reversing that trend. It will delay our G network, but so be it. Boris Johnson had little choice once US sanctions made the Chinese tech giant even less trustworthy.Meanwhile, though, China is still investing heavily in nuclear power here. How safe is that GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: face masks cafe ministers confusion
story: But this morning Matt Hancock said customers paying for food at a counter at cafes such as Pret a Manger or Costa would have to cover up. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Government found itself in further chaos today after ministers were unsure whether or not masks needed to be worn when buying take away food. No said this afternoon: It wouldnt be mandatoryyou went in, for example to go into a sandwich shop to wear a face covering. It is mandatory for shops rather than food shops.But Mr Hancock told Sky News this morning: You do need to wear a face mask in Pret because Pret is a shop - in hospitality, there needs to be table service.If theres table service, it is not necessary to have a mask. But in any shop, you do need the mask. So,youre going up to the counter in Pret to buy takeaway that is a shop, butyou go to your local pub you cant go to the bar.The reason is because of the risk of transmission over the bar. A spokesman for the Department of Health said this morning face masks would need to be worn at the counter, but not when customers eat and drink. The new rules will make face masks compulsory from July  in England and people will face a £ finethey fail to comply.Mayor of London Sadiq Khan tweeted: This is frankly ridiculous. The virus doesnt knowyoure in a take-away or a supermarket.The Government is risking the health of the public to cover the back of a Cabinet Minister. Please wear a face covering in all shops and take aways.The bungled message on masks in cafes comes after Environment Secretary refused to rule out masks in offices yesterday, only for Mr Hancock to say  hours later they would definitely not need to be worn. Mr Hancock said today: “The reason for that is when you are in close proximity with somebody who you have to work closely with,you are there for a long time then a mask does not offer that protection, as opposed to a shop or public transport when you are with someone for a reasonable amount of time.“The point is when you are in interaction with people you aren’t normally with, that’s when the mask is particularly helpful.Mr Hancock was slammed by Lorraine Kelly this morning for the Governments relaxation of rules. She said the measures to stop the spread of coronavirus had been smashed to smithereens. Labour Shadow Health Minister Justin Madders said the Governments muddle over masks was just hopeless. He said: We have had mixed messages from Government all week and it seems that once again they are making it up as they go along.“We need clear and consistent messages about when the wearing of a face covering will be compulsory not attempts at redefining what a shop is.“Public safety and confidence are key to preventing a second wave and the Government need to raise their game in ensuring that everyone knows when the wearing of a mask is required.”Government guidance already advises people to wear masks where they are indoors and unable to social distance but yesterday Michael Gove was spotted leaving a Pret without a mask. Mr Hancock said the photo was taken before the policy was formally announced. But Liz Truss, another Cabinet minister, sported a blue mask coming out of the same Pret in Westminster. People could also be banned from entering shopsthey do not have a mask and Mr Hancock urged shops to call the policepeople enter without one. title: priti patel coronavirus uk
story: The Home Secretary today revealed she did not know the number of infected coming into Britain, but insisted the figure was held “where” in the Government.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIn a heated Home Affairs Committee, chair and Labour MP Yvette Cooper asked for an “estimate” of the amount coming in.Ms Patel answered: “Well that I don’t know. “On a daily basis, the number of people coming into the country is approximately , people and that’s across all modes of transport.“I don’t have a figure of people coming into the country with coronavirus.“That figure is held centrally where across Government.”However, later the Home Offices chief scientic adviser, John Aston, wrote in a letter to Ms Cooper that the number was insignicant and did not have an impact on the spread of the disease.An estimate provided by Government advisers SAGE on the  March for people coming from overseas to the UK who had coronavirus was . per cent of domestic cases, which is insignicant to the spread of the epidemic.But no exact number was given as he said any resulting estimate would be reliable.On May  Ms Patel announced the Government was enforcing a new quarantine measure to prevent a second wave of Covid-.The measures meant all visitors entering the UK would to self-isolate for  days starting from June , with spot checks and fines for those caught breaching the rules.Todays committee saw a seething Ms Cooper challenge the Home Secretary over the quarantine, and suggest Ms Patel had not even asked how many infected had slipped through.She said: “What is the Government’s estimate “Shona Dunn told us in the last session that you had never asked for an estimate of how many people might be coming into the country with coronavirus.”Ms Patel denied the accusation, but again failed to give a number.She said: “The figure that I was given [in March was] . per cent of people will potentially bring in cases from outside of the UK into the UK.”Ms Cooper responded that the senior minister had given the same answer at the last evidence session, only to be corrected.She added: “Were you ever given, did you ever ask for, and were you ever given an estimate of the number of people coming into the country with coronavirus.”Ms Patel insisted: “It was dficult to get accurate information and I have asked.”She also claimed there was “no point asking”“hypothetical figures are accurate”.The member of the cabinet also insisted most people were following quarantine rules at the border, but admitted the Government were only doing spot checks on about  per cent of those coming in.Speaking after the meeting, Ms Cooper claimed it seems Home Office neither knows nor has ever asked for those figures.Boris Johnson had previously defended the quarantine as a useful way to keep numbers down.The Prime Minister had said: “Now that we’re getting the virus under control in the UK, there is a risk cases from abroad begin once again to make up a greater proportion of overall cases.“We need to take steps now to manage that risk of these imported cases triggering a second peak.”However, the Government’s chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance suggested it was the wrong time for quarantine.He said the controls were most effective during the early stages of a pandemic but added it was for the politicians to “make the policy and make the timing decisions”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jen reid black lives matter statue bristol
story: The statue was erected in secret on the morning of July . But who was the statue of and what happened to it  Here is everything we know...The toppled statue of slave owner Edward Colston was replaced by a sculpture of a Black Lives Matter activist in Bristol on July , .Artist Marc Quinn created the black and resin steel structure of a Black Lives Matter protester. A team of  people, directed by the artist, erected the figure of the black woman at  am. Two lorry loads of activists arrived in Bristol to raise the statue, using a hydraulic crane truck - before council officials could intervene.A cardboard sign reading Black Lives Still Matter was placed at the bottom of the plinth.Jen Reid is a stylist who attended the original Black Lives Matter march where the Colston statue was toppled.During the march, Ms Reid was photographed on the empty plinth after the Colston statue was toppled.Artist Marc Quinn said he had crystallised the moment Reid stood on top of the empty plinth on  June and raised her fist aloft in a black power salute.On the morning it was erected Ms Reid stood in front of the “absolutely beautul” statue, fist raised, telling the : “I’d better get a picture before they take it down.This is going to continue the conversation.Not officially. The statue was erected by artists but it remains unofficial.Bristol council removed the statue as it was put up without their permission. Bristol mayor, Marvin Rees, tweeted on July : I understand people want expression, but the statue has been put up without permission.Anything put on the plinth outside of the process weve put in place will have to be removed.A Bristol City Council spokeswoman said: This morning we removed the sculpture.It will be held at our museum for the artist to collect or donate to our collection.  Pictures from the scene in Bristol showed workers at the site at around : am.Council workers used ropes to secure the statue of Jen Reid before removing it and loading it into a recycling and skip hire lorry.The Edward Colston statue was pulled down by protesters in June - however, Bristol City Council is yet to decide what will officially replace it.It was dragged to the harbourside, where it was thrown into the water at Peros Bridge - named in honour of enslaved man Pero Jones who lived and died in the city.Bristol City Council retrieved the statue, which will be displayed in a museum along with placards from the Black Lives Matter protest, from the water on June .Colston worked for the Royal African Company in the th century and was later a Tory MP in Bristol.The statue of him by sculptor John Cassidy was erected in .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris announces coronavirus inquiry
story: The Prime Minister insisted now was not the time to start analysing how well the Government has responded to the pandemic but pledged to have one in the future. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMr Johnson told the House of Commons this lunchtime: I do not believe that now, in the middle of combatting a pandemic, as we still are, is the right moment to devote huge amounts of official time to an inquiry. Of course, we will seek to learn the lessons of this pandemic in the future and certainly we will have an independent inquiry into what happened. Officials said there was no date yet for an inquiry but it would come forward in due course.Its also not clear how much it might cost, who would lead the inquiry, and how long it would last.Many of the Governments top ministers have also stressed that it is too soon to start calling for an inquiry into coronavirus. There have been almost , deaths from coronavirus in the UK - the highest death toll in Europe. A report for Government scientists this week said a second wave in the winter could kill , people. One of the biggest issues MPs are keen to examine is how coronavirus wrought havoc in care homes. Questioning the PM today, Liberal Democrat MP Sir Ed Davey said: We have suffered one of the worst death rates in the world and Europes worst death rate for health and care workers. A report by the National Audit Office, assessing the readiness of the NHS and the social care sector for coronavirus, showed it was not known how many of the , people discharged from hospitals into care homes were infected with coronavirus. A fth of the nations most vulnerable people in care home have been infected by the deadly virus. There are also questions surrounding the Government decision to go into lockdown weeks later than many other European countries. The PM has backflipped on ious policies, including face masks - which will be mandatory from July  - but were previously not used because of claims they did not work. MPs have launched their own inquiry earlier this week with an All-Party Parliamentary Group, led by Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran. Ms Moran said earlier this week: From the neglect of care homes to the lack of an effective testing regime, each day brings more evidence of mistakes in the handling of this pandemic – and there is every indication that we will see a potential second spike this winter.“The country and the NHS cannot afford for these errors to be repeated. There is no time to waste when it comes to learning the lessons from the UK response to the pandemic.This is why we are launching our parliamentary inquiry and will be taking evidence immediately.” To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: farmhouse sanctuaries sprawling 11m ranches 480k horses and cattle celebs shunning city living for the country
story: Especiallyyou’re a multimillion-pound celebrity, willing to splash the cash on a luxurious ranch or farm retreat.Forget camping, or roughing it in a cramped cabin - here, we take a look at the celebrities shunning the bustle of the city in favour of a more relaxed rural setting, albeit still on a blow-out budget…A far cry from their £m Hollywood Hidden Hills mega mansion estate, Kim and Kanye are said to have loved le on their £m, , acre ranch in Wyoming so much, they splurged another £m on a second , acre property in the same area.Situated  miles from Yellowstone National Park, it’s where the family have spent much of lockdown, and the original luxurious sprawling country estate boasts two fishing lakes, a working horse barn and cattle.In the past Kim has described it as “the prettiest place you’ve seen in your entire le,” and it’s clear the family have developed a love for the great outdoors - albeit from the comfort of their impressive estate, which boasts a saloon and a restaurant on site.The family also own  Friesian horses - a rare breed which can reportedly cost up to £k each - and Kim has relished the opportunity to have her kids learn how to horse ride and be at one with nature.While the Beckhams can boast a y property portfolio - featuring a London townhouse, Dubai beach pad and Miami penthouse - they chose to spend lockdown in their stunning rural retreat.Their Cotswolds ranch was a Grade II-listed farmhouse that was converted into a sprawling country mansion when they bought it in December  for a hefty £.million.David and Victoria have gone with a traditional ranch-like aesthetic for their not-so humble abode, which features exposed brick walls, huge open fireplaces, and wooden beams running across the low ceilings - fitted with gorgeous spotlighting.The outside of the property is equally magnicent as they enlisted a Cha Flower Show winner to fulfil their vision of creating a fairytale garden complete with a natural swimming plunge pond, traditional Estonian sauna, sprawling lawns and an expansive decking area.Whats more, David and Victoria have been granted planning permission to build a secret tunnel under the property to act as an escape route, as well as build a wine cellar and extend their garage - like its not already huge.The incredible home has played host to some star-studded events, including birthday parties and baptism celebrations, and most recently the propertys fields became the backdrop of Brooklyn Beckham and Nicola Peltzs engagement snap.When they’re not jetting around the world gracing the catwalk and modelling for some fashion’s biggest names, pregnant Gigi Hadid, , who is expecting her first baby with Zayn Malik, and her sister Bella Hadid, , love nothing more than relaxing at their mother Yolanda’s -acre Pennsylvania farmhouse.The famous sisters both live in Manhattan, so the £.m rural retreat provides the perfect escape from the hectic bustle of New York.But don’t expect the family to be roughing it while there - the property has its own horse stables, garden, fire pit and even a botanical gardenAccording to Vogue, the family have embraced farm le, by picking lavender, making candles and creating crystal labyrinths so they can meditate.Speaking to Elle, Yolanda said: “It’s where we can all come and feel like ourselves again.“When I’m here, I just get in my truck and go to the store.“Kids get excited at the market, but they don’t take their phones out.It turns out former One Direction star Zayn loves Gigi’s family farm so much, he snapped up his own rural retreat nearby in Pennsylvania, to escape the glare of the spotlight and grow his own crops, including tomatoes and cucumbers.Speaking to Billboard, Zayn revealed why he loves the country le, saying it’s “out of the way and feels grounded … I do a lot of farm work.“I take the horses out and feed the cows and that kind of stuff. It’s cool.“I’ve always been interested in animals.”Kristin Cavallari rose to fame on popular MTV series Laguna Beach, but it seems the reality star was only too happy to swap the golden sands of Calornia for the £.m farm house she bought with now-estranged husband Jay Cutler in Nashville, Tennessee.The pair purchased the , square foot, eight bed hobby farm in , which also boasts  acres of land, a chicken coop, horse stables and a goat barn.The daily farmyard chores provided content for their reality TV show, Very Cavallari - including removing poo from their brood of  baby chick’s behinds.And it seems the task was an eye opener for the mum of three, with Kristin saying: “Living out on a farm, I’ve learned quite a few things and one of those is that, baby chicks, you have to clean their butts … becausethey can’t poop, they’ll die.”Queen of TV chat shows and worth a cool bn, obviously Oprah Winfrey wouldn’t buy just one country retreat.She has a £m ranch, named ‘The Promised Land’ in Montecito which is a property set on  acres of land, with both mountain and ocean views.Also within her property portfolio are a £m, -acre horse farm in the same area featuring four bedrooms, five baths, a pool and a filled fish pond, as well as a  acre farm in Hawaii.The star has a particular connection to the country, having grown up on a small farm in Mississippi, where her grandmother grew all their food.Writing about growing up on Oprah, the presenter said: “We churned the butter, we milked the cows, we killed the hogs, we cured the meat in the smokehouse. Above all, we tended our little garden.“Thats where most of what we ate came from. And now Ive ed to that way of living: We eat whats from the garden.”When not living in LA, actor Chris Pratt spends his time at his rural farm house in Washington, raising sheep, two pigs called Tim and Faith, and a herd of cows.In fact, the -year-old star’s flock of livestock are award-winning, with one ewe’s fleece taking home a blue ribbon at the local farming show.Speaking about farm le, his pregnant we Katherine Schwarzenegger told E! News: “It’s a fun adjustment. I have grown up with a bunch of dferent animals, so it feels very comfortable and at home and just a beautul part of le.”While plenty of celebs are hopping on the farming bandwagon, one thing’s for sure after taking a closer look at their rural retreats.It’s not like any camping holiday we’ve been on.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: parliament could move york westminster
story: NewsParliament could move to York while Westminster renovated, Boris Johnson suggestsIn a letter, Boris Johnson says that locations outside London should be considered as a review is under way on how to handle the repair works at Parliament, which some estimates state could cost £ billionShareByShaun ConnollyOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  JUL News " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Prime Minister has suggested Parliament could move to York while the Palace of Westminster undergoes a multi-billion pound refurbishment.In a letter, Boris Johnson says that locations outside London should be considered as a review is under way on how to handle the repair works at Parliament, which some estimates state could cost £ billion.Mr Johnson wrote: Costs should be kept to a minimum . We should also move as quickly as possible. The PM said that the case for both Houses staying in place should be considered but that other locations should be in the mix. He stated: However, the review should also consider a possible location outside London. The Government is considering establishing a Government hub in York and it would therefore make sense to consider this as a potential location. The comments came after a new consultation process was launched last month which considered whether MPs and peers would need to vacate the historic building as work is carried out. In the letter to people involved in the review, the PM said: We should also move as quickly as possible, both because of the risks associated with the current state of the building and the need to provide certainty on the way forward and thereby minimise disruption to our business. Before Parliament voted in  to approve the renewal works, which will entail decanting the whole building for at least six years, MPs had pushed rival plans that would have seen only a partial vacating required. This would have forced builders to work around the Commons schedule.The idea has since gained traction again following the coronavirus outbreak.A recent report by the National Audit Officestated that the £ billion cost previously reported for the project was likely to be a median figure, with the final outlay on the Unesco World Heritage Site expected to be higher. Initial estimates put the final bill as high as £ billion, with the builders expected to be in until the s. The body said that a team will assess whether a recommendation made in a report four years ago that all MPs and Lords should leave the Palace of Westminster while the work was carried out is still the best and most cost-effective option.

title: tory who raised energy pipeline
story: NewsTory who raised energy pipeline in Commons shared fundraiser table with donors behind itEXCLUSIVE Backbencher David Morris has accepted a total of £, in donations from Aquind Ltd - and shared a table with the firms directors and Business Secretary Alok Sharma at the notorious Black and White BallShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  JUL NewsTory Backbencher David Morris " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Tory MP who asked a Commons question about a controversial energy firm was a guest of the donors behind it at a lavish fundraising dinner. Backbencher David Morris was handed a £, donation from Aquind Ltd in September . A month later, he asked Energy Minister Kwasi Kwarteng a question relating to the company in the House of Commons, urging him to lobby energy watchdog Ofgem to change regulations that could benefit Aquind. Mr Kwarteng replied that he would. Mr Morris insisted he had not broken any rules, because he had drawn attention to the register of members’ interests before asking his question. When details of the first donation emerged, Mr Morris told the Times: “No breach of conduct has occurred as the declaration is clearly stated before the question was raised in Hansard as in accordance with the House of Commons rules. Yesterday it emerged Business Secretary Alok Sharma had recused himself from decisions regarding Aquind, a £. bn energy scheme to run a huge electrical cable under the English Channel. Mr Sharma said he would have no part in decisions on the project after accepting a £, donation from the firm and sharing a £, table with the businessmen behind it at the Toriesapos notorious aposBlack and White Ballapos. Today the Mirror can reveal Mr Morris also sat at the same table, alongside Aquindaposs Russian directors, Alexander Temerko and Kirill Glukhovskoy. It can also be revealed that Mr Morris accepted a further £, donation from Aquind in December, two months after his question in the Commons. There’s no suggestion of any wrongdoing on the part of Aquind Ltd, Mr Temerko, Mr Glukhovskoy or Mr Morris. A Number  spokesman said: “Political parties raise funds in the normal way in line with the regulations and law.  In total, Aquind Ltd donated more than £, to nine inidual Conservative MPs in the last year. Added to donations made to the national party, the figure rises to £, since . A spokesperson for Mr Sharma said: “Alok formally recused himself from the process months ago, and has not and will not have any involvement in the decision on this proposal.” It’s understood decisions on the project will now be taken by Mr Kwarteng

story: NewsBritish nuclear submarine in near miss with ferry with hundreds on boardRoyal Navy has been rapped over a near miss between a passenger ferry and a nuclear-powered submarine in the Irish Sea which saw them yards from disaster as the ferry - with hundreds on board - was forced to take evasive actionShareCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  JUL NewsThe near miss was caught in this eyewitness picture. The submarines periscope can be seen from the ferry " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA ferry with hundreds of people on board narrowly avoided hitting a British nuclear-powered submarine after a watch officer spotted its periscope just  yards ahead. The potentially massive maritime disaster came after the crew of the partially submerged sub had underestimated the ferry’s speed and distance. But the Stena Line ship’s quick-thinking officer took “immediate and effective action” to avoid the collision in the Irish Sea, a report has revealed. The crew of the Royal Navy submarine had spotted the Stena Superfast V vessel seven minutes earlier – calculating its distance at , yards. But they turned across its path believing they had time to get clear.A two-year probe found the sub thought it was , yards away when the ferry swerved.It was actually a quarter of that. The sub is part of Britain’s nuclear-powered fleet, although it is not knownit was one of four that carry nuke missiles. The near-miss took place in  but the report into what could have been the UK’s worst sea disaster in years was released only tonight. It was played down by authorities at the time and its severity has only just emerged.It was also revealed it was the third time in four years that a submerged Royal Navy submarine had narrowly missed a collision. Andrew Moll, Chief Inspector of Marine Accidents, said: “The lookout on board the ferry spotted a submarine’s periscope close ahead. “The Officer of the Watch then took immediate and effective action, turning the ferry to avoid a genuine risk of collision.”  He says underestimating the ferry’s speed and position led to “safety-critical decisions being made on inaccurate information”. The report adds that the ferry assessed “an imminent risk of collision [and] the OOW [Officer of the Watch] told the lookout to adopt hand-steering and, at :, ° of port rudder was applied.”And it warns: “This was the third [such] accident or incident in four years, which is a matter of signicant concern.” The Maritime Accident Investigations Branch said the control room’s electronic tactical display “presented a picture of a safer situation than reality.” The roll-on, roll-off ferry operates between Belfast and Cairnryan in Scotland, carrying up to , passengers. It set sail at .am on November  with  passengers and  crew, and was an hour and  minutes into its trip.

title: just weeks left find new
story: NewsOur little princess urgently needs new organs – just like other children waiting for callEXCLUSIVE: A one-in-a-million illness means Thalia, , needs urgent heart and lung transplant - but its a race against time with a desperate quest to find organs the right sizeShareCommentsByMatthew Barbour:,  JUL Updated:,  JUL NewsThalia-Beaus organ dream is for a heart and lungs" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThey were just five words but they changed ­everything: “Thalia is on the list.” After seemingly endless months of waiting, five-year-old Thalia-Beau Wright was eligible for the heart and lung transplant she needed. But while it meant she could have the le-saving surgery at last, it also marked the beginning of a ­desperate quest to find organs. Thalia has a condition called restrictive cardiomyopathy, which her grandmother Christine Johnson compares to “a ticking bomb”. Christine said: “She could have days, weeks or months. We just don’t know. We got the call we’d waited for for so long. I can’t put into words what that call meant.” The family are all too aware it will be a race against time for the child. But even in their hour of need they have made it their mission to appeal for potential organ donors – to save not just Thalia’s le but all the hundreds of other children waiting for that call. “We’re still a long way off,” ­Christine said. “We need a healthy heart and lungs that’s not just from someone with a blood group that is compatible with Thalia’s, but also approximately the same size. Thalia is one in a million andwe don’t have hope, we don’t have anything. Now we have hope like we haven’t felt in years.” The little girl was diagnosed with the heart condition in  a few days after her fourth birthday and the arrival of her brother Rudy. With no cure or treatment, the family was told her only hope lay in finding her new organs. But she was only assessed as being in enough need or fit enough to go on the list last week. She is in high dependency at Leeds General Infirmary after battling pneumonia and is the only child in the UK on the urgent donor waiting list for a heart and lungs. If or when that call finally comes, she will be blue-lighted to Great Ormond Street Hospital in London to replace her organs with healthy ones and give her a chance at le. Thalia’s mum Ellie-Mae, , from Scarborough, North Yorks, said: “Within a week our family went from the euphoria of having a new baby to ­absolute devastation. “Thalia was so excited about turning four and having a little brother. It was like a kne had been placed in our hearts. “Thalia is the most energising, smiley little girl in the world, and for her to finally be on the list is what we’ve been praying for for so long. Of course we’ve a long way to go yet but this last week has felt like a massive step forwards.” Restrictive cardiomyopathy is an exceptionally rare muscle disease which stfens the ventricles around the heart, causing it to become enlarged.  Doctors at Scarborough Hospital noticed Thalia’s was swollen after she was admitted with a chest infection. She was quickly transferred to Leeds General Infirmary where the family were given the nightmare diagnosis. Then began the tortuous waiting game. “It was – and still is – the most horrible state of limbo, trying to pretend everything was normal, Thalia unable to understand how all the odds were stacked against her,” said Christine, , who helps care for her with her husband Simon, , Thalia’s grandfather.    After two further stays in Leeds General Infirmary, Thalia was then referred to the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle for a heart transplant assessment. But Thalia wasn’t deemed to be a viable candidate because by then she had pulmonary hypertension, a secondary disease to her cardiomyopathy, meaning she now also needed a double lung transplant. Thalia was then referred to Great Ormond Street Hospital for a second opinion. She did relatively well for a long time after that initial diagnosis, Christine says, enjoying many largely carefree days at the family beach chalet near their home in Scarborough, starting school and a trip of a letime to Disneyland Paris.  However,  brought a rapid decline in her health, with infections and complications meaning more time in hospital. The family shared Thalia’s story on social media to raise awareness of organ donation and to champion the NHS.Their Facebook page now has almost , followers and Thalia has met heroes including Lewis Capaldi and Jason Manford – although she still wants to meet her biggest idol, Stormzy.Christine said: “We’d never heard of restrictive cardio­myopathy, as the chances of having it are exactly what Thalia is to us... one in a million. She’s the most bubbly, sassy, beautul little girl, inside and out. It breaks all our hearts to think about what she’s got, what the future holds. “It’s such a hard thought to take in, knowing that another family’s whole world will come crashing down so that ours can be saved. “But the heart-breaking reality is that tragedies happen every day, where lives can’t be saved. It’s in those terrible circumstances we hope families can find it in themselves to save a le like Thalia’s.” Sadly this isn’t the first time the family have faced a member needing organ donation. Christine’s nephew and Thalia’s cousin, Alistair Haythorne, , has received three kidney transplants to date.He is currently on dialysis and will hopefully be listed for a fourth transplant in the near future – making the family all too aware of the need for organ donors. Nearly  children have died in the UK in the past  years waiting on the organ donor transplant list.  Angie Scales, NHS Blood and Transplant lead nurse for paediatric donation, says: “It’s so important for families to talk about organ donation and to include their children in those conversations. By saying yes to organ donation, families are in a position to give another family hope. “Donor families tell us they take great pride and comfort from the knowledge that they have helped to save lives.” Simon said the family has been contacted by “countless strangers around the world” saying how they have been inspired by Thalia to sign up to organ donor registers.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMeghan Markle has set her sights on becoming President of the United States, according to Beverly Turner.The presenter told Channel aposs Jeremy Vine that she had it on good authority that the Duchess of Sussex intends to run for office.Meghan and Prince Harry moved back to the United States in January and have have been vocal on a number of political matters such as Black Lives Matter and climate change. America is set to go to the polls in November with Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden looking increasingly likely that he will replace incumbent Donald Trump.Ms Turner said: She will run for President, I have no doubt about it. Ms Turner asked: What do you mean by woke  Opinionated   Mr Vine responded: Woke is not aligning with where consensus is now, I suppose that is the thing.The Duchess of Sussex has hit out at the treatment by “those in the corridors of power” in her first speech since quitting her role in the royal family. In a pre-recorded video, Meghan spoke to the Girl Up  Leadership Summit, as part of a session called The Time Is Now. Speaking from her Los Angeles home, Meghan, , said: “I want to share something with you. “It’s that those in the halls and corridors and places of power, from lawmakers and world leaders to executives, all of those people, they depend on you more than you will ever depend on them. “And here’s the thing: they know this. “They know that all of you, at a younger age than any modern comparison, are setting the tone for an equitable humanity. Not figuratively, literally. “This is a humanity that desperately needs you.  “To push it, to push us, forcefully in a more inclusive, more just, and more empathetic direction. “To not only frame the debate, but be in charge of the debate—on racial justice, gender, climate change, mental health and wellbeing, on civic engagement, on public service, on so much more. “That’s the work you’re already out there doing.” Meghan and husband Prince Harry left their royal roles officially in March and now live in a friend’s borrowed £million mansion. In recent weeks they have criticised the Commonwealth’s “uncomfortable past” while Meghan has hit out at her treatment at the hands of the royal family saying she felt “unprotected”.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBig families living in terraced houses are at the centre of new coronavirus outbreaks sweeping across Lancashire. Packed housing is one of the reasons people in Blackburn, Darwen and Pendle have been advised to wear face masks indoors to avoid local lockdowns. In the borough of Blackburn with Darwen household visiting has been reduced to one household plus two members from another household. Officials say infections are spreading rapidly among ethnic minority communities who live in big families. Director of public health Prof Dominic Harrison said: “These steps will help and we are appealing to everyone in Blackburn with Darwen to follow them to protect themselves and their loved ones. “If we don’t, a local lockdown, like in Leicester, becomes a very real possibility.” He added: “We know that they are in mainly south-Asian areas, and they are in areas with high number of terraced houses with high numbers of occupants in the house, so four or more, five or more people in the household.” Follow all coronavirus updates here on our live blog He said % of the  new cases were people from South Asian backgrounds. More lockdown measures would be introducedcases were not falling by July . Council leader Mohammed Khan said: “Le cannot go back to normal just yet, and we must all make sacrices to avoid a local lockdown. “Please continue to do your bit to stick to the rules to protect yourself and your family.” It comes as the Government is set to make a decision soon on whether to extend the city-wide lockdown in Leicester. There the rate has risen from  per , of population, up to  in the week ending Saturday. But this is down from . in the seven days to  June. Pendle has also advised residents to “limit large extended family gatherings inside” after recording the second highest number of cases in the country at . per ,. It saw a dramatic increase, particularly in the Nelson and Brierfield areas, in the week up to Saturday from . per ,. It also has a large ethnic minority population. Lancashire’s director of public health Dr Sakthi Karunanithi said: “We need your help now to... keep Pendle out of lockdown.” Other towns with high infection rates include Rochdale, Bradford, Peterborough and Luton. Stricter measures to curb the virus have been introduced in Blackburn and Darwen in Lancashire, following  new cases in the past week. Confirmed cases in the Blackburn with Darwen borough has gone up to  per ,. This is a rise from . cases in the seven days to July . The local authority of , people has called on people to bump elbows in place of handshakes and hugs. Residents are being told to wear cloth face coverings in all enclosed public spaces, including workplaces, libraries, museums, health centres and hair and beauty salons.  Prof Harrison said: “We have what we call a rising tide event rather than an outbreak. “By that we mean that we’ve got a number of cases rising in specic areas across a signicant community, but not a single big outbreak like other areas that had a workplace outbreak. “And when we look at the data what we can see is clusters in a part of the town, but the clusters are household clusters.” Big families looking after elderly relatives may be a factor in outbreaks but officials have warned against stigmatising certain ethnic groups. Around a third of Blackburn with Darwen’s , population are from ethnic backgrounds, with a large Pakistani heritage population. Blackburn councillor Saima Afzal said: “It should be a concern to anybodyany community is stigmatised and we know the facts are there, we are open about those facts.” “You go home and you are caring for a family member, or there are three or four families living under one household, because of economic reasons, or financial issues. “The Asian community do do that, they pool their resources together to help the whole family survive.

Meteorologist Clare Nasir said Thursday will be a better day all around than yesterday outside of the northwest of the country, with highs of C and sunshine for many. North and southeast Scotland, northeast England, eastern parts of Wales and central southern England will be the favoured spots for seeing some sunshine. However, he added that temperatures over the weekend are going to slowly ebb away due to strengthening wind and patchy rain - though Saturday will still see highs of C and Sunday C in the south.  The hot and dry weather wonapost be felt by all, with Ms Nasir warning a bank of rain and wind will arrive across western Scotland this evening, moving down across central Scotland and Northern Ireland. On Friday, she said: Many of us will see some brighter weather - it will feel warmer south of the rain band, with some sunshine coming through. That rain band pushes down towards the far north of England, [and] extends towards northern parts of Wales.  She added: Into the weekend it continues its passage southwards, with some fresher air to arrive in the north and also some sunshine. The Met Officeaposs long-range forecast has warned any sustained heatwaves are unlikely, however, until at least the middle of August. One even decided to don medical gloves to hide her youthful skin on her hands, while the mask covered her young face. Unsurprisingly, several video posts have gone viral, with some in the millions of views. Some describe the videos as apospranksapos but others were quick to point out it was illegal. On TikTok, one -year-old said she used baby powder in her hair and tucked some into a scarf to make her look aposmatronlyapos. Complete with sunglasses and face covering, she managed to buy a bottle of wine without being challenged. Excited, she tells her followers she is shaking.She added thatshe had been challenged to provide ID, she would have said I had forgotten it in the car and left the store. Another viral hit shows a girl of unknown age apply her costume in her bedroom before driving to a shop. Accompanied by pals, she puts on an OAP mask from a costume shop, with fake hair that covers her face.  Her mates film her secretively as she walks through the shop, mimicking the frail gait of an elderly lady. She emerges victorious with a shopping bag packed with tins of booze, as her friends laugh excitedly. While some have crazed the teens for their creativity, others point out it is illegal and that posting the evidence on social media might not be the smartest move.  In the UK, everyone will have to wear face coverings inside a shop nine days from now. The new rules, which come into play on July , are being welcomed by most in the medical community. If you fail to cover your face while visiting a supermarket or High Street shop you may be fined £.

story: NewsWoman, , held in Nigerian hotel for year after toy boy lures her with marriageChukwuebuka Kasi Obiaku allegedly met the -year-old American woman on Facebook and invited her to come to Lagos in Nigeria under the "pretext of love and marriage"ShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  JUL NewsChukwuebuka Kasi Obiaku allegedly lured a woman her met on Facebook to Nigeria and kept her locked up in a hotel for a year " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . In February  the woman made the journey and three months later married Obiaku. Sadly their relationship quickly fell apart, leading the husband to hold his we captive in a hotel for more than a year, Mba said in a statement. During that time he allegedly set about making money by forcing the woman to use her American accent in scams. Obiaku is accused of getting her to ask organisations for money over the phone by acting as several dferent characters, including as a nanny. Mba said that he also used her credit cards and collected  months worth of retirement payments. Obiaku has yet to be charged with a crime, although he allegedly told police the wedding in Lagos was a ruse. The woman was eventually rescued after police received a tip-off about the case from another Nigerian.

title: dundee sports club anxious to start work on new 3g pitch
story: A club is battling against the clock to ensure Dundee youngsters will be playing football on a new G pitch by autumn.Fairfield Community Sports hub has secured most of the funding and are hopeful that work on the £, pitch at Fairfield Park on Drumgeith Road can begin in the next few weeks.If that window of opportunity is lost, the project will be delayed until next year.Director Jim Sorrie said: #We have now raised £, for the pitch and are just waiting to hear from Dundee City Council who have already promised us £, to go towards the cost.#Once the final money is secured we can start work.#The contractor has told us he could start as early as next week. The work would take around eight to  weeks which means that we could potentially be up and running by September.#Jim said that in the past the club have fallen victim every winter to weather conditions which frequently leaves their pitches unplayable for the entire season.The club applied for permission for a new state-of-the-art G pitch in , which was granted the following year.Jim said: #It has taken us a while to get this far and obviously lockdown didn#t do us any favours.#Let#s just hope we can move quickly before this winter season comes and we have the new pitch in place by then. We are now very anxious to get started on this as soon as possible.#If we can#t get started on the work very soon we will be into another winter season, and we will have lost our chance to get the pitch developed this year.#The club#s sports officer John Cairney said: #The pitch will be a massive boost for the community and will reach out to many of hundreds of local children  and will also provide a venue for all age and abilities.#The hub currently have  clubs under the banner of St James Community Club who would all  benefit greatly from the G facility. #He added: #The hub are also in the planning stage for creating a new cycling club for local participants, this again will help support with social isolation, and building new friendships.#We are also looking to attach a bike maintenance group.#A Dundee City Council spokesman said: #We will talk directly to the group about any issues they raise with the council.#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: dundee united micky mellon mark ogren
story: Dundee United boss Micky Mellon has revealed he has the backing of owner Mark Ogren in the transfer market.Mellon, who signed a two-year deal to be United’s new manager last week, was assured by the club’s American owner he’ll be able to strengthen his squad in the summer window.However, the -year-old gaffer plans to take his time to assess the current crop first before working with sporting director Tony Asghar to improve the Tangerines’ pool.“It’s a bit early and a bit unfair on the champions of the Championship,” the former Tranmere Rovers man said.“They deserve great respect. It’s been a great shame they haven’t been able to celebrate that.“The club will find some way of they get their day with that.“In terms of recruitment and brining players in, I’ll give the players here the opportunity.“I’ll take my time with that. Assurances is a strong word but certainly Dundee United as a club would have the ability to go out and do that,I can bring players that would make Dundee United a better team.“They’d have the ability to go into the market and bring players in that could make the team better.“If the need is there for me to go and do that, and the opportunity to bring players in from other places I believe is a good fit for the culture of the club and making the team better, then absolutely we would have the ability to do that.“The owner has told me he’d back me as has Tony Asghar and I’m happy with that.”As for how United’s embroilment in Hearts and Partick Thistle’s legal case against the SPFL affects his ability to spend, Mellon says that is for those higher up at Tannadice to say.An SFA arbitration  will hear the Jags and Jambos’ petition this week with league champions United, Raith Rovers and Cove Rangers mounting their own defences in the wake of the initial SPFL resolution and Court of Session action.“I think that’s a question for other people,” he said of the impact United’s legal costs on his playing budget.“I’ve, obviously, been brought here to try to improve a football team.“I’m here try to build relationships with fans and connect everybody, to make players understand the sacrices you need to make to improve and the other stuff will be taken care of by specialists.“They’ll get on with that, that’s what they’re here to do and paid to do, that’s not my remit.“I’ll do what I’m here to do which is digest training, see what I think our players need to do I order to keep moving them forward and then get out on the grass to put on sessions that will challenge them.“Once I see the improvements that need to be made, I’ll be strong with them and keep the standards really high.“I need to keep them fit and motivated and away we go. I’ll do that every day.“That’s just the way I work and operate as a manager. It’s stood me in good stead and I won’t change that.”Mellon’s track record in developing players is impressive with Leicester star Jamie Vardy one of his students at Fleetwood Town and Manchester City ace John Stones another at Barnsley.However, the Paisley-born coach was keen to point out another in Rangers defender Connor Goldson, whom Mellon had at Shrewsbury.He hopes to repeat those kind of successes at United.He added: “I had Connor Goldson. We developed him into a fantastic centre-back and sold him to Brighton for millions.“You take your time with them and see what they need to get better at. It was the same with Vardy, Stones and these kind of guys.“You look at it and know the qualities that’s needed for them to be a top player.“You recognise it and because I’ve been through it before and been successful with it before because the proof is there with the boys playing at unbelievable levels, I’m able to bring that to this group of players.“I know the techniques that are needed to show them. The training sessions or talking to them about things in a way they can grasp and understand to make them top players as well.“I really enjoy doing that and I’m so proud of all the boys who have turned out top players.”CALUM WOODGER: New Dundee United boss Micky Mellon is making all the right noises" title"#CALUM WOODGER: New Dundee United boss Micky Mellon is making all the right noises# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp calum-woodger-new-dundee-united-micky-mellon-making-right-noises embed # secretZZoTJol" data-secret"ZZoTJol" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite.
